annotation.TEXT: Elec Man's section is easily the most annoying one, if mostly due to how the enemies' Thunder Beams interact with the stage. Each time they hit one of those spheres, it creates a spread shot that gets reflected (usually towards a spot that provides the most inconvenience for you). As you can probably imagine, there's some pretty evil set-ups that can be made with this gimmick.

You can generally tell which RM is being copied based on the enemy's palettes alone. Here, it's Ice Man, at least for the first section anyways. Just to note, I'm not sure if the Ice Slashers actually deal more damage to Fire Man or not (though if they do, it's some nice attention to detail).

The final stage itself is basically a long gauntlet with a majority of the enemies from the main stages, but with a unique twist to it: The enemies now use abilities based on each of the Robot Masters you play as. Admittedly, this sort of comes out of nowhere, but it's still a way better idea for the final stage when compared to a simple boss rush.

Overall, if you want to play a game where you take on the roles of the Robot Masters, skip this and go straight to Day in the Limelight 2 (or go play Powered Up, for that matter). Thanks to the votes, the sequel to this game is up next. Aside from showcasing how much better it is compared to this game, I have something special planned for it as well...

The final Wily stage is another good candidate for being the longest one in the game, though not for the reasons you might suspect. Interestingly enough, there are actually no boss refights here. To the game's credit, it instead does something far more interesting (although you might not be able to see it right off the bat, considering the rather awful clip-show quality in this first area).

On a special note, Bomb Man's phase is both the easiest and the absolute worst part of this fight. Wily might have a simple way of moving around, but he's also capable of killing you in two hits should you bump into him. I'm a little surprised I haven't run into this type of issue before in these fan-games, but I feel it needs to be addressed: Easy bosses/patterns do not warrant insane damage output. It's a cheap (and quite frankly, lazy) alternative to just giving the boss a better pattern.

As mentioned before, the sequel to this game is far superior in almost every single way - so much in fact, that it kind of makes this game obsolete by comparison. Trust me, you don't need to play this first game for the sake of "context" when going into the second one.

Now that we're out of the "clip-show" area, here's Bomb Man's section. While it's not quite as annoying as Elec Man's area, it can still be frustrating due to how much damage everything deals. Kaminari Goros are all through-out this section, though the bombs they throw aren't too difficult to avoid. Rather, it's the Battons you need to watch out for (since they actually explode once you kill them).

Another transition effect up ahead (even though I would normally restart after multiple deaths, I think it's evident by now that I just wanted to get this done). Either way, Wily isn't any more difficult than some of the other bosses in this game. In fact, aside from the high damage output, he's relatively simple.

Cut Man's section isn't too difficult. The "Cutter Joes" can be a bit annoying at times, but they're actually more manageable than the usual variety. The only thing I find annoying about this section is the new hazard (which I think further proves that the creator had way too much Super Mario World on their mind).

The short answer: No. The slightly longer answer: It hasn't aged well at all. The only reason I could see anyone coming back to this thing is for the sake of novelty value, and really, that's essentially all this first game exists as anymore. It presents unique and fine ideas to be sure, but there's so many problems that drag it all down and make it unenjoyable to play.

Of course, that's not actually the end. The true last stage leads straight to the final boss. The last fight with Wily is actually a multi-stage battle, where you use all of the Robot Masters against him (fortunately, they don't share the same health bar). For the most part, it's relatively easy to figure out what to do for each part (save for a few things, such as the weird way Cut Man's attacks interact with certain things during his phase).

Transition effect (since I died in this area soon afterwards, and the check-point is right here). Anyways, here's Guts Man's section. Much like with the original weapon they're copying, the debris from the enemies' rocks tend to go all over the place. Fortunately, it doesn't really turn into a bullet hell situation at any point (especially since the Changkey Makers' rocks produce a diagonal pattern).

And...That's it, actually. This cast sequence is the only bit of credits you get after beating the game. Since it's relatively short, I'm going to have to be quick with my summary. So then, is this game actually worth playing?
